APPENDIX
              Appendix A
City of Alexandria Scoping Agreement
July 9, 2014

Kevin Cosimano, Principal
StonebridgeCarras, LLC
7200 Wisconsin Avenue
Suite 700
Bethesda, Maryland 20814-5332

RE: Oakville Triangle
    Supplemental Attachment to Scoping Intake Form



Mr. Cosimano:

This letter serves as a supplement to the Oakville Triangle Transportation Scoping Intake Form.

DESCR IPT ION OF DEVELOPMENT
StonebridgeCarras is planning to pursue a redevelopment of the existing uses in the Oakville
Triangle, located west of US 1 in Alexandria, bordered by Calvert Avenue to the north, Fannon Street
to the south, and the Mt. Jefferson Trail to the west. The development project will replace a mix of
highway-oriented uses with a mixture of housing, retail, and hotel development in a walkable, urban
form.

As a part of the redevelopment process, the City of Alexandria has requested that StonebridgeCarras
participate in a small-small area planning process as well as the normal Development Special Use
Permit (DSUP) process associated with the development of land in the city. The study area is shown
in Figure 1.




 kimley-horn.com   11400 Commerce Park Drive, Suite 400, Reston, VA 20191              703 674 1300
                                                                                 Page 2




                                        Figure 1: Study Area




kimley-horn.com   11400 Commerce Park Drive, Suite 400, Reston, VA 20191   703 674 1300
                                                                                                   Page 3


Study Area

The study area intersections are:

    l    U.S. 1/ E. Reed Avenue
    l    U.S. 1/ E. Glebe Road
    l    U.S. 1/ Swann Avenue
    l    U.S. 1/ E. Custis Avenue
    l    U.S. 1/ E. Howell Avenue
    l    U.S. 1/ Potomac Avenue
    l    Potomac Avenue/ E. Glebe Road
    l    Potomac Avenue/ Swann Avenue
    l    Potomac Avenue / E. Custis Avenue
    l    Potomac Avenue / E. Howell Avenue
    l    Commonwealth Avenue/ Mt. Vernon Avenue
    l    Commonwealth Avenue/ E. Glebe Road
    l    Mt. Vernon Avenue/ E. Custis Avenue

SITE TRIP GEN ERAT ION AND MODE SPL IT

A trip credit will be claimed for the removal of the existing uses in the Oakville Triangle. Table 1
shows the trip generation of the existing uses of Oakville Triangle at the intersection of Swann
Avenue and Route 1:

Table 1: Existing Trip Generation at Swann Avenue

                        AM Peak Hour              PM Peak Hour
   Intersection
                     Total    In    Out        Total   In    Out
 Swann Avenue         95     58      37         94    45      49


It is recognized that the figures above do not represent the total traffic generated by the existing uses
of the Oakville Triangle. The total trip generation of the existing uses of the Oakville Triangle is
assumed to be double the trips that are observed at the Swann Avenue intersection. This assumption
has been accepted by City Staff. The trips generated by the existing uses of the Oakville Triangle are
shown in Table 2:

Table 2: Existing Trip Generation at Oakville Triangle Entrances/Exits

                                                  AM Peak Hour                   PM Peak Hour
             Intersection
                                          Total        In          Out   Total       In          Out
           Fannon Street                   31          19          12     31         15          16
          Calvert Avenue                   48          29          19     47         23          24
         Raymond Avenue                    16          10           6     16          7           9
           Swann Avenue                    95          58          37     94         45          49
  Total Existing Oakville Triangle        190         116          74    188         90          98




 kimley-horn.com     11400 Commerce Park Drive, Suite 400, Reston, VA 20191                 703 674 1300
                                                                                                           Page 4


The existing trip generation figures in Table 2 will be removed from the study area network based on
the trip distributions described in subsequent sections of this letter.

Site trip generation figures are based on the rates found in the 9th Edition of the Institute of
Transportation Engineers Trip Generation Manual.

The developer plans on implementing a phased construction and opening of the Oakville Triangle
property. Phase 1 is planned to be completed by 2018 and Phase 2 is planned to be completed by
2021. Phase 1 development levels are based on gross estimates of land use provided by City Staff.
Phase 1 person-trip generation figures, without the consideration of mode split reductions, are
provided in Table 3 below.

Table 3: Phase 1 Person-Trip Generation


                                DU /             AM Peak Hour              PM Peak Hour
      Use             Code                                                                        Daily
                                SF
                                             Total      In     Out      Total    In      Out
 Residential          223     550 DU            212     66     146      253     147     106      2,151
    Retail            826    45,000 SF           32     14      18      129      57      72      1,963
High Turnover
                      932    30,000 SF          324    178     146      296     178     118      3,815
 Restaurant
                   Total                        568    258     310      678     382     296      7,929


Mode split reductions are be assumed due to the proximity of nearby transit facilities. Mode split
reduction factors are based on the factors used in the December 2009 Potomac Yard Multimodal
Transportation Study as shown in Table 4 below. Restaurant land uses are assumed to have the
same mode split as retail.

Table 4: Mode Split

              Use                   Transit-      Transit – Metrobus,     Pedestrian and       Auto       Total
                                    Metrorail      Dash, CCPY-BRT        Bicycle (non-auto)
  Office adjacent to a transit
                                       35%               11%                    6%             48%    100%
             station
   Office within ¼ mile of a
                                       21%               9%                     6%             64%    100%
         transit station
  Residential adjacent to a
                                       54%               1%                     16%            29%    100%
         transit station
Residential within ¼ mile of a
                                       48%               1%                     15%            36%    100%
         transit station
 Residential with ¼ to ½ mile
                                       31%               5%                     10%            54%    100%
           of Transit
              Hotel                    27%               4%                     31%            38%    100%
   Entertainment (theater)             26%               6%                     11%            57%    100%
    Retail and Restaurant
                                       29%               8%                     27%            36%    100%
(excluding large format retail)

BACKGRO UND DEVELOP MENT S
City staff has provided a list of approved and unbuilt background developments to include in the
analysis of future conditions:

    l     South Potomac Yard Landbay G
    l     South Potomac Yard Landbay H
    l     South Potomac Yard Landbay I
    l     South Potomac Yard Landbay J
    l     South Potomac Yard Landbay L
    l     North Potomac Yard (Landbay F)
    l     Other Development Projects
          n  The Dorn Building
        n    Tony’s Corner
        n    Del Ray Greens (Anthony Auto Extension)
        n    East Reed AHC Multifamily
        n    East Reed Townhomes
        n    Marino’s Restaurant Expansion
        n    Jefferson Davis Warehouse
        n    Alexandria Toyota Extension
Staff has also provided a determination of what portion of the developments will be completed and
occupied or open at the time of Phase 1 Build-out, Phase 2 Full Build-out, or Phase 2 Full Build-out
plus 6 years of Oakville Triangle.


In addition to the developments listed above, Staff has forecasted the proposed development levels
on the remaining portions of the Oakville Triangle Small-Small Area Plan study area. The traffic
generated by these remaining portions will be considered as additional site generated traffic.


Mode split reduction factors will be applied all developments as specified above.




 kimley-horn.com    11400 Commerce Park Drive, Suite 400, Reston, VA 20191                   703 674 1300

Staff has provided a list of planned transportation improvements to be included in the analysis of
future conditions:

    l   By 2018
        n    Route 1 BRT
        n    Potomac Yard Metro Station

Trip Distribution
Trip distribution for the proposed land uses are based on the values identified in the December 2009
Potomac Yard Multimodal Transportation Study and are described in Table 8 and shown graphically
on Figure 2.

Table 8: Trip Generation

 To/From                                                            Distribution
 To/From North on Route 1                                              26%
 To/From Northwest on S. Glebe Road                                     7%
 To/From North on George Washington Memorial Parkway                    3%
 To/From West on Reed Avenue and E. Glebe Road                         10%
 To/From West on Custis Avenue and Monroe Avenue                       12%
 To/From South on Route 1 and Washington Street                        30%
 To/From North on Potomac Avenue                                       12%
 Total                                                                 100%

ANALY SIS MET HODOLOGY
The study intersections will be analyzed using Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) Methodologies and
the Synchro Software Package. Analysis will be performed for existing conditions, Phase 1
conditions, Phase 2 Full Build-Out conditions, and Phase 2 Full Build-Out plus 6 years. Analysis will
consider the AM and PM commuter peak hours of travel.

VISSIM modeling of the study network will be as specified by the City of Alexandria Transportation
Study Guidelines.

INT ERNAL C APT URE
Internal capture between land uses is assumed to be represented by the pedestrian and bicycle
mode split reductions. No additional Internal Capture will be calculated. This is in accordance with the
methodologies used in the December 2009 Potomac Yard Multimodal Transportation Study.

PASS-BY
As the planned on-site retail is not large format, no pass-by trips reductions will be assumed for the
on-site retail uses in accordance with the methodologies used in the December 2009 Potomac Yard
Multimodal Transportation Study. A pass-by trip percentage of 43% of PM trips will be assumed for
high-turnover (sit-down) restaurant uses in accordance with the methodologies of the ITE Trip
Generation Manual.




 kimley-horn.com    11400 Commerce Park Drive, Suite 400, Reston, VA 20191                703 674 1300
                                                                                  Page 8




                                       Figure 2: Trip Distribution

*Cells in yellow indicate roughly estimated block length Block lenths are reported for informational purposes only and do no indicate the amout of storage
for through movements. In most instances block length is reported as "distance to next unsignalized intersection/distance to next signalized intersection"


**Block length for Eastbound Glebe Road reported as "distance to Clifford/distance to Laverne"
m - Volume for 95th percentile queue is metered by upstream signal.
~ - Volume exceeds capacity, queue is theoretically infinite. Queue shown is maximum after two cycles.
# - 95th percentile volume exceeds capacity, queue may be longer. Queue shown is maximum after two cycles.

TOTAL PROJECTED DEVELOPMENT                                      203,385                  -                                            1,128,896             490                                        1,890,450                       200

Projections represent occupied new development square footage by year specified (not additive)

Notes:

A] Projections for the area of Oakville Triangle and Route 1 Corridor Plan Study Area excluding The Blackstone Group parcels include a 90% residential and 10% commercial use mix.
B] These are preliminary numbers and projections will be subject to the on-going community planning process. The North and South Potomac Yard development projections are based on construction of the Metrorail Station at Alternative B. The Metrorail
Station is projected to be operational by 2018. In the event that the planning process amends these numbers, and/or that another Metrorail Alternative is selected, the projections and traffic study will need to be updated and refined.

C] "Commercial" uses in the table above include Office and Retail uses. Hotel square footage is based on 500 square feet per key (room).
D] The projections for South Potomac Yard in 2018 do not include occupied units (development between 2010-2013)
E] In North and South Potomac Yard, townhouse/stacked townhouse units are assumed to be 2000 square feet and multifamily units are assumed to be 1000 square feet.

Grade (%)                               3%                           -2%                          -1%                      0%
